title: SB 1.18.36-37 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 23-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananjan Shalakaya Chakshurun Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: The son of the Rishi, his eyes red hot with anger touched the water of the river Kaushiki while speaking to his playmates and discharged the following thunderbolt of words.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verses to be discussed and begins explaining the 36th verse, focusing on the anger of the Rishi's son.

segments.key_quote: Parikshit while hunting became very thirsty, tired, hungry, starved.
segments.summary: The speaker provides the background story of King Parikshit's actions that led to the curse, including his thirst, hunger, and disrespect towards the meditating Rishi.

segments.key_quote: So when the son of this Rishi, Shringi heard that his father was insulted by the king, the boy Shringi became very angry against this insult
segments.summary: The speaker describes the Rishi's son, Shringi, his anger upon hearing of the insult to his father, and his preparation to curse the king.

segments.key_quote: The mantra power is such that it is like a weapon, but it is not actually a, a gross weapon. It is a subtle weapon.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the power of mantras, comparing them to subtle weapons, and emphasizes the potency of the curse.

segments.key_quote: the circumstances under which Maharaj Parikshit was cursed were simply childish as it appears from this verse.
segments.summary: The speaker quotes Srila Prabhupada's commentary, highlighting the childishness and impropriety of Shringi's actions and the great harm caused by cursing the king.

segments.key_quote: On the seventh day from today a snake bird will bite the most wretched of that dynasty Maharaj Parikshit because of his having broken the laws of etiquette by insulting my father.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces and translates the 37th verse, which contains the actual curse pronounced by Shringi, citing Parikshit's breach of etiquette as justification.

segments.key_quote: Thus the beginning of the misuse of brahmanical power began.
segments.summary: The speaker quotes Srila Prabhupada on the misuse of brahmanical power, explaining how Shringi's curse marked the beginning of the decline of brahmanas in the Kali Yuga.

segments.key_quote: But factually the brahmana boy himself was so by cursing Parikshit this brahmana boy became the most wretched descendant of the glorious brahmana lineage.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how Shringi's curse made him the 'wretched' one, leading to the loss of brahmanical power in his lineage.

segments.key_quote: Similarly in this Kali Yuga the brahmanas are powerless because Sringi misuse that is where the misuse began and that misuse continued for some time till most of the brahmanas became powerless.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a snake with broken fangs to illustrate the powerlessness of brahmanas in Kali Yuga due to the misuse of their power, concluding the lecture.
